llm_processed_output.source_summary: Contemporary research, referencing scholars like Jean Devisse and Mohammed Kably, establishes a correlation between the power of Western Muslim rulers (starting with the Almoravids) and their subsequent decline.  This correlation links the rise of trade between the Maghreb and sub-Saharan Africa from the 11th century with the initial power of these dynasties. Conversely, the resurgence of eastern African trade routes in the latter half of the 14th century and the rise of Egypt and Portugal in the 15th century is correlated with the decline of these Berber dynasties. The control over gold routes by Berber dynasties, manifested in the administrative and political importance of cities like Sijilmâssa, Tlemcen, Aghmât, Ceuta, and Almería (which were established as governorates with mints during the Almoravid period), is highlighted as a key factor.  While this correlation has been seen as overly deterministic by some, the text concludes that the rise of powerful states in Western Muslim Maghreb was contemporary with the mediating role of Maghreb rulers and merchants between sub-Saharan regions and the Mediterranean, while their disappearance coincided with the rise of Egypt and Portugal.  The high-quality gold ('tibr') imported from sub-Saharan Africa played a significant role in the economies and power of these dynasties.
